	<item>
		<title>Innovating with a Rock-Solid Foundation While Saving 40% on Networking Costs: Imagine Learning&#8217;s Journey with Linkerd</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/07/14/innovating-with-a-rock-solid-foundation-while-saving-40-on-networking-costs-imagine-learnings-journey-with-linkerd/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Blake Romano, Senior Software Engineer, Imagine Learning]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Jul 2025 23:44:07 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=138365</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[At Imagine Learning, we strive to empower educators and inspire breakthrough moments for over 18 million students across the United States. As a digital-first education solutions provider, our mission is to deliver robust, reliable, and secure...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p></p>



<p>At <a href="https://www.imaginelearning.com/">Imagine Learning</a>, we strive to empower educators and inspire breakthrough moments for over 18 million students across the United States. As a digital-first education solutions provider, our mission is to deliver robust, reliable, and secure experiences to support the boundless potential of K-12 learners. Achieving this at scale‚Äîspanning hundreds of thousands of daily users‚Äîrequires a technical foundation as innovative as our products.</p>



<p><br>To meet these demands, our engineering team has embraced modern cloud-native technologies. The cornerstone of our infrastructure is <a href="https://linkerd.io/">Linkerd</a>, supported by <a href="https://www.buoyant.io/">Buoyant</a>, running on Amazon&#8217;s Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS). Linkerd gives us the critical capabilities that we need to scale effortlessly while maintaining the performance and reliability that our users depend on.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Delivering Reliability and Security at Scale</h3>



<p>Our users‚Äîstudents and educators‚Äîdepend on fast, reliable, and secure access to our digital tools. Dropped traffic, slow load times, or security issues in the face of ever-evolving threats would disturb the user experience, potentially leading to customer churn. For that reason, reliability and security are a top priority for Imagine Learning. As our platform grew to include hundreds of microservices deployed across several Kubernetes clusters on AWS EKS, managing communications at scale to avoid these problems became extremely challenging. We needed a solution that would:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Encrypt traffic seamlessly.</li>



<li>Simplify service-to-service communication.</li>



<li>Provide deep observability into application-layer (L7) networking.</li>
</ul>



<p>In short, we needed a service mesh.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Linkerd: Opting for Simplicity, Performance, and Security&nbsp;</h3>



<p>After evaluating multiple service mesh options, Linkerd stood out due to its simplicity, performance, and security. Unlike other solutions, Linkerd uses a tiny <a href="https://linkerd.io/2020/07/23/under-the-hood-of-linkerds-state-of-the-art-rust-proxy-linkerd2-proxy/">Rust-based sidecar microproxy</a>, offering a small compute footprint, significantly reduced CVEs, and enhanced overall security. Linkerd‚Äôs ease of configuration allowed us to deploy it reliably and scale it within hours, enabling our team to focus on delivering value to our customers.</p>



<p>Additionally, <a href="https://docs.buoyant.io/buoyant-cloud/getting-started/what-data-does-buoyant-cloud-collect/">Buoyant Cloud</a> has amplified Linkerd‚Äôs capabilities by providing real-time metrics and intuitive alerting. This ensures that our operations team can swiftly diagnose and resolve issues, maintaining an exceptional user experience.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Building a Scalable and Observable Platform</h3>



<p>Our engineering team integrated Linkerd with several other CNCF tools to create a robust platform:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Argo CD: Enables GitOps workflows, ensuring consistent deployment of Linkerd across all clusters.</li>



<li>Argo Rollouts: Enable us to roll out to customers progressively using Linkerd‚Äôs Gateway API Integration informed by metrics.</li>
</ul>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXe6nKR-NOLtnwiw4Pm3T0Jvq_Ne73LikCh2A35QMk6htV-gY-s-a-xio605BOjXbPX41C5elEvIQ-NzrR2sd0eyhhjKko7J85gIls8xJbMOvs_qGNejjIlmj_eFnYOrwzn4NJdQDg?key=_fhJw1ohr7wmtuIs99B5_25z" alt="Image of Spoke Clusters"/></figure>



<p>We started the implementation by adopting the <a href="https://glossary.cncf.io/gitops/">GitOps</a> mindset: our Kubernetes manifests are stored in Git, and we use <a href="https://argoproj.github.io/">Argo</a> CD to deploy resources into our Kubernetes clusters. Argo CD manages Linkerd, Argo Rollouts, the microservices our application teams build, and the other components needed for our platform. Additionally, <a href="https://www.buoyant.io/linkerd-enterprise">Buoyant Enterprise for Linkerd</a> provides a simple Helm chart to deploy its lifecycle Operator, which makes it easy to manage our Linkerd deployments with a single custom resource. Once deployed, all meshed pods were automatically mTLSed!</p>



<p>Next, we started leveraging the <a href="https://gateway-api.sigs.k8s.io/">Gateway API </a>in our environment to use Argo Rollouts with their Gateway API plugin. We now use Argo Rollouts for canary deployments, enabling controlled rollout of new application versions to our customers: Linkerd seamlessly changes the amount of traffic going to the new version based on Argo Rollouts‚Äô instructions, and Argo Rollouts uses Linkerd‚Äôs HTTP metrics to understand whether a rollout is going successfully. This allows us to minimize the impact customers could experience due to a release deficiency.</p>



<p>Together, these tools in this architecture allow us to maintain a highly observable and manageable Kubernetes environment. With Linkerd, service-to-service communication is secure and reliable, while Buoyant Cloud‚Äôs metrics enable proactive performance management.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Transformational Gains</h3>



<p>The adoption of Linkerd has yielded significant technological and business benefits:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Reduced Operational Overhead by 20%: By streamlining service mesh management, we‚Äôve cut the time spent on operational tasks by a substantial margin.</li>



<li>Enhanced Efficiency: Linkerd‚Äôs lightweight design reduced the compute requirements of our service mesh by over 80% compared to our previous service mesh implementation.</li>



<li>Reduce Costs: Buoyant Enterprise for Linkerd‚Äôs High Availability Zone Load Balancing with Linkerd is on track to reduce our regional data transfer networking costs by at least 40%.</li>



<li>Improved Reliability: Real-time observability ensures rapid issue resolution, translating to better user experiences and fewer disruptions.</li>



<li>Improved Security: Linkerd has reduced the amount of service mesh-related CVEs we have been exposed to by 97% in 2024.</li>
</ul>



<p>On a personal level, these improvements mean fewer fire drills for our engineers, allowing them to focus on innovation.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Looking Ahead</h3>



<p>As we continue to scale, Imagine Learning remains committed to leveraging cloud-native technologies like Linkerd to deliver exceptional educational experiences. With a solid foundation on AWS EKS, powered by the reliability and support of Buoyant and Linkerd, we are poised to inspire breakthrough moments for millions of students every day.</p>
]]></content:encoded>
					
		
		
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Konnichiwa, Yokohama! KubeCon + CloudNativeCon returns to Japan in 2026</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/07/08/konnichiwa-yokohama-kubecon-cloudnativecon-returns-to-japan-in-2026/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Chris Aniszczyk]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Wed, 09 Jul 2025 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=137458</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[The inaugural KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Japan 2025 was an overwhelming success. There were more than 700 speaking session submissions. Registrations and sponsorships completely SOLD OUT.&#160; This is why I‚Äôm thrilled to share KubeCon + CloudNativeCon will...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>The inaugural KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Japan 2025 was an overwhelming success. There were more than 700 speaking session submissions. Registrations and sponsorships completely <strong>SOLD OUT</strong>.&nbsp;</p>



<p>This is why I‚Äôm thrilled to share <a href="https://events.linuxfoundation.org/kubecon-cloudnativecon-japan-2026/" data-type="link" data-id="https://events.linuxfoundation.org/kubecon-cloudnativecon-japan-2026/">KubeCon + CloudNativeCon will return to Japan in 2026</a>‚Äîand this time, we‚Äôre heading to the beautiful port city of <strong>Yokohama!¬†</strong></p>



<p><strong>Save the dates: </strong>29-30 July 2026</p>



<p>From vibrant community meetups to globally recognized innovation in cloud native technologies, Japan has been a strong contributor to CNCF‚Äôs Asia-Pacific growth. After the success of KubeCon + CloudNativeCon in Tokyo, we can‚Äôt wait to once again bring the community together in a place where cutting-edge technology meets rich cultural heritage.</p>



<p><strong>Yokohama Makes Sense</strong></p>



<p>As Japan‚Äôs second-largest city, Yokohama is a global innovation hub, particularly for startups. It‚Äôs thriving tech scene, world-class infrastructure, and a long-standing spirit of international collaboration‚Äîmaking it the perfect setting for the next KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Japan.</p>



<p>The <strong>Pacifico Yokohama</strong> venue allows us to grow, offering ample space for maintainers, end users, contributors, and ecosystem partners to connect in person, share best practices, and continue pushing the cloud native landscape forward.&nbsp;</p>



<p><strong>What to Expect in 2026</strong></p>



<p>More, more, and more:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Technical sessions and maintainer track deep dives</li>



<li>International perspectives and local innovations from Japan and beyond</li>



<li>Networking with peers, contributors, and open source leaders</li>



<li>Opportunities to learn, grow, and give back to the community</li>
</ul>



<p>But Yokohama isn‚Äôt just about conference halls‚Äîit‚Äôs about sushi by the bay, futuristic architecture, and maybe even a ride on the Cosmo Clock Ferris Wheel. Combining education and fun KubeCon + CloudNativeCon is known for.&nbsp;</p>



<p><strong>Stay Tuned &amp; Get Involved</strong></p>



<p>Planning is underway, and we‚Äôll be sharing updates on the <strong>Call for Proposals (CFP) </strong>and registration in the months ahead. If you are interested in sponsoring, visit <a href="https://events.linuxfoundation.org/kubecon-cloudnativecon-japan-2026/">2026 KubeCon + CloudNativeCon Japan</a> for information.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In the meantime, mark your calendars for <strong>29-30 July 2026</strong> and plan to meet us in Yokohama.</p>



<p>We can‚Äôt wait to welcome you to another unforgettable gathering of our global community. Let&#8217;s continue building the future‚Äîtogether.</p>



<p>See you in Yokohama!<br>Chris Aniszczyk<br>CTO, Cloud Native Computing Foundation<br><a href="https://twitter.com/cra">@cra</a></p>



<p></p>
]]></content:encoded>
					
		
		
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Why Policy as Code is a Game Changer for Platform Engineers</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/07/08/why-policy-as-code-is-a-game-changer-for-platform-engineers/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jim Bugwadia, co-founder and CEO of Nirmata]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Tue, 08 Jul 2025 15:46:21 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=136699</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[Originally posted on Nirmata&#8217;s blog. Platform engineers, let&#8217;s talk about a fundamental shift that&#8217;s revolutionizing how we build and manage internal developer platforms: Policy as Code (PaC). This isn&#8217;t just another buzzword; it&#8217;s the key to...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p></p>



<p>Originally posted on <a href="https://nirmata.com/2025/05/13/why-policy-as-code-is-a-game-changer-for-platform-engineers/">Nirmata&#8217;s blog</a>.</p>



<p>Platform engineers, let&#8217;s talk about a fundamental shift that&#8217;s revolutionizing how we build and manage internal developer platforms: Policy as Code (PaC). This isn&#8217;t just another buzzword; it&#8217;s the key to creating scalable, secure, and efficient operations that empower developers. Let‚Äôs dive in!</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Empower Developers with Faster Feedback</strong></h3>



<p>PaC drastically improves developer experience. By implementing policy checks early in the development process (&#8220;shifting left&#8221;), developers get instant feedback on potential issues. This prevents problems from reaching production and reduces mental load, allowing them to focus on innovation, not compliance headaches.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Enable Secure Self-Service</strong></h3>



<p>Platform engineering is about giving developers self-service capabilities. Infrastructure as Code (IaC) provides automation, but Policy as Code (PaC) provides the critical guardrails. Developers can provision resources and deploy applications within defined &#8220;golden paths,&#8221; ensuring agility without compromising security or compliance.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Achieve Unprecedented Transparency</strong></h3>



<p>Policies written as code are stored in version control, creating a clear history of changes. This auditability is essential for troubleshooting and demonstrating compliance. The code itself provides transparency for all stakeholders.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Boost Efficiency and Scalability</strong></h3>



<p>Manual policy enforcement is unsustainable. PaC automates policy management, allowing you to efficiently manage policies across a growing infrastructure without increasing manual effort.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Ensure Consistent and Standardized Environments</strong></h3>



<p>Say goodbye to configuration drift and the dreaded &#8220;it works on my machine&#8221; issues. PaC allows you to codify best practices, configuration standards, and architectural patterns, enforcing them across all environments. This results in fewer surprises and a more predictable development landscape.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Automate Governance and Security</strong></h3>



<p>Instead of manual checklists and scattered scripts, PaC embeds governance and compliance rules directly into your pipelines. Automate the enforcement of security policies, resource limits, and naming conventions, freeing up time and reducing the risk of errors.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Fortify Your Security Posture</strong></h3>



<p>PaC is a powerful tool for proactive security. Define security configurations, access controls, and data handling requirements as code, and automatically enforce them. This dramatically reduces misconfigurations and strengthens overall security.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Streamline Compliance Effortlessly</strong></h3>



<p>Compliance doesn&#8217;t have to be a bottleneck. Translate complex mandates like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS into code, providing an auditable and automated way to ensure adherence to standards.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>The Future of Platforms is Policy as Code</strong></h3>



<p>Policy as Code is a fundamental building block for effective platform engineering. By adopting PaC, you can create robust, compliant, and developer-friendly platforms that accelerate innovation while maintaining necessary control and governance.</p>



<p>Policy as Code is the future, today, and projects like¬†<a href="https://github.com/kyverno">Kyverno</a> can help support this.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Explore More About Platform Engineering</strong></h3>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li><a href="https://dzone.com/articles/platform-engineering-for-cloud-teams">Platform Engineering for Cloud Teams &#8211; DZone</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.pulumi.com/blog/the-guide-platform-engineering-idp-steps-best-practices/">The Guide to Platform Engineering: 7 Steps to Get It Right | Pulumi Blog</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.wiz.io/academy/policy-as-code">What is Policy as Code (PaC)? | Wiz</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.port.io/blog/work-with-platform-engineering-team">Best practices to work with a platform engineering team &#8211; Port IO</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.crowdstrike.com/en-us/cybersecurity-101/cloud-security/policy-as-code/">What is Policy as Code (PaC)? &#8211; CrowdStrike</a></li>



<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cyberpedia/what-is-policy-as-code">What Is Policy-as-Code? &#8211; Palo Alto Networks</a></li>
</ul>
]]></content:encoded>
					
		
		
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Kmesh v1.1.0 Officially Released!</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/07/03/kmesh-v1-1-0-officially-released/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Lexi Wang]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 Jul 2025 13:31:00 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=136720</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[We are excited to announce the release of Kmesh v1.1.0‚Äîa major milestone shaped by contributions from our global community, including key support from LFX Project participants, whose dedication have been pivotal in driving this release forward....]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>We are excited to announce the release of <a href="https://github.com/kmesh-net/kmesh/releases/tag/v1.1.0">Kmesh v1.1.0</a>‚Äîa major milestone shaped by contributions from our global community, including key support from LFX Project participants, whose dedication have been pivotal in driving this release forward.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXcyhUMnZ49FlJAm3mG38OqgTjW1mdcW_ZAA03BWLDNzo6eZLa6Qh8BDSxJDmhgXwwQiqwl0fUkpnsPxlF0dCBfN3mc7YGj8b1-fv54s9M8iBzLQanWSRgVWYJah8x-bpib0W0_F?key=CmMj7kY7U8IfOGOHfQNUWg" alt="Picture of KMESH logo"/></figure>



<p>Building on the foundation of v1.0.0, this release introduces significant enhancements to <a href="https://kmesh.net/">Kmesh</a>‚Äôs architecture, observability, and ecosystem integration. The official Kmesh website has undergone a comprehensive redesign, offering an intuitive interface and streamlined documentation to empower both users and developers. Under the hood, we‚Äôve refactored the DNS module and added metrics for long connections, providing deeper insights into more traffic patterns.</p>



<p>In Kernel-Native mode, we‚Äôve reduced invasive kernel modifications. Also, we use global variables to replace the BPF config map to simplify the underlying complexity. Compatibility with ‚Äã‚ÄãIstio 1.25‚Äã‚Äã has been rigorously validated, ensuring seamless interoperability with the latest Istio version. Notably, the persistent TestKmeshRestart E2E test case flaky‚Äîa long-standing issue‚Äîhas been resolved through long-term investigation and reconstruction of the underlying BPF program, marking a leap forward in runtime reliability.&nbsp;</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Main Features</h1>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Website overhaul</h3>



<p>The Kmesh official website has undergone a complete redesign, offering an intuitive user experience with improved documentation, reorganized content hierarchy and streamlined navigation. In addressing feedback from the previous iteration, we focused on key areas where user experience could be enhanced. The original interface presented some usability challenges that occasionally led to navigation difficulties. Our blog module in particular required attention, as its content organization and visual hierarchy impacted content discoverability and readability. From an engineering perspective, we recognized opportunities to improve the code structure through better component organization and more systematic styling approaches, as the existing implementation had grown complex to maintain over time.</p>



<p>To solve these issues, we rebuilt the site using <strong>React and Docusaurus</strong>‚Äîa modern, developer-friendly documentation framework. This allowed us to create modular components, eliminating redundant code through reusability. Docusaurus provides built-in navigation systems specifically designed for documentation and blogs, plus version-controlled documentation features. We&#8217;ve implemented multilingual support with both English and Chinese documentation, added advanced search functionality, and completely reorganized the content structure. The result is a dramatically improved experience that makes the Kmesh site more accessible and valuable for all users.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Long connection metrics</h3>



<p>Before this release, Kmesh provides access logs during termination and establishment of a TCP connection with more detailed information about the connection, such as bytes sent, received, packet lost, rtt and retransmits. Kmesh also provides workload and service specific metrics such as bytes sent and received, lost packets, minimum rtt, total connection opened and closed by a pod. These metrics are only updated after a connection is closed.&nbsp;</p>



<p>In this release, we‚Äôve added continuous access logging and metrics for long-lived TCP long connections.Access logs are reported periodically with information such as reporting time, connection establishment time, bytes sent, received, packet loss, rtt, retransmits and state. Metrics such as bytes sent and received, packet loss, retransmits are also reported periodically for long connections.</p>



<p>DNS refactor</p>



<p>The current DNS process includes the CDS refresh process. As a result, DNS&nbsp; is deeply coupled with kernel-native mode and cannot be used in dual-engine mode.&nbsp;</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXdN9aHfNOzx9pZ8XBpvL4T51BLJZUzu4Zv52EeQbWnvR_57s6iP8vzL4bq1htHNe7BNUG8VHOpmhwQlLemRrWE2vn1WekAYo3fub9BB_FW12-yghQb5MPTWzG6mhKcOyYKKRHllyg?key=CmMj7kY7U8IfOGOHfQNUWg" alt="Picture of AdsController"/></figure>



<p>In release 1.1 we refactored the DNS module of Kmesh. Instead of a structure containing cds, the data looped through the refresh queue in the Dns is now a domain, so that the Dns module is now decoupled from Kmesh‚Äôs operating mode, focusing solely on hostname resolution.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXfyW0GYBRTzC2Xys5_iPoNRyb4M9fpFCMc9rOz0IzYLKplxhyeO802N8u3l0Wjqgh0m8Lf9DdQUh9pfQdeOpyyVDh-20qpbqoatGuNnx61cdekJvV7ysnjiI2woJD7koq7gVlUu5Q?key=CmMj7kY7U8IfOGOHfQNUWg" alt="Picture of DNS module in Kmesh"/></figure>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">BPF config map optimization</h3>



<p>Kmesh has eliminated the dedicated kmesh_config_map BPF map, which previously stored global runtime configurations such as BPF logging level and monitoring toggle. These settings are now managed through global variables. Leveraging global variables&nbsp; simplifies BPF configuration management, enhancing runtime efficiency and maintainability.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Optimise Kernel Native mode to reduce intrusive modifications to the kernel</h3>



<p>The kernel-native mode requires a large number of intrusive kernel reconstructions to implement HTTP-based traffic control. Some of these modifications may have a significant impact on the kernel, which makes the kernel-native mode difficult to deploy and use in a real production environment.</p>



<p>To resolve this problem, we have modified the kernel in kernel-native mode and the involved ko and eBPF synchronously. With this release, we‚Äôve optimized kernel-native mode to reduce intrusive kernel modifications. In Linux kernel 5.10, the changes are now limited to four; in kernel 6.6, just one remains‚Äîwith plans to remove it entirely.. This last one will be eliminated as much as possible, with the goal of eventually running kernel-native mode on native version 6.6 and above.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXfNa9CTAyDkWVRD3bUYGo1KpZc4iDHBgYzuZExC457RpDtdAAv9ZJFe4erfNstGJaaX_RHMViIVHL4f8s_g0nH_vcLgPBGeieIaAxxmyKQZgx6QUDlGUCJNaGSZesibCkapACbO4w?key=CmMj7kY7U8IfOGOHfQNUWg" alt="Picture of modified the kernel in kernel-native mode"/></figure>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Adopt istio 1.25</h3>



<p>Kmesh has verified compatibility with istio 1.25 and has added the corresponding E2E test to CI. The Kmesh community maintains verification of the three istio versions in CI, so the E2E test of istio 1.22 has been removed from CI.</p>



<h1 class="wp-block-heading">Critical Bug Fix</h1>



<p>1. kmeshctl install waypoint error (<a href="https://github.com/kmesh-net/kmesh/issues/1287">https://github.com/kmesh-net/kmesh/issues/1287</a>)</p>



<p>2. TestKmeshRestart flaky (<a href="https://github.com/kmesh-net/kmesh/issues/1192">https://github.com/kmesh-net/kmesh/issues/1192</a>)</p>



<p>Acknowledgment</p>



<p>Kmesh v1.1.0 includes 118 commits from 14 contributors. We would like to express our sincere gratitude to all contributors:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-table"><table class="has-fixed-layout"><tbody><tr><td>@hzxuzhonghu</td><td>@LiZhenCheng9527</td><td>@YaoZengzeng</td><td>@silenceper</td></tr><tr><td>@weli-l</td><td>@sancppp</td><td>@Kuromesi</td><td>@yp969803</td></tr><tr><td>@lec-bit</td><td>@ravjot07</td><td>@jayesh9747</td><td>@harish2773</td></tr><tr><td>@Dhiren-Mhatre</td><td>@Murdock9803</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table></figure>



<p>Kmesh is built with openness and vendor neutrality at its core. We‚Äôre proud to contribute to a healthy, scalable future for sidecarless service mesh.. Kmesh is currently in a stage of rapid development, and we sincerely invite people with lofty ideals to join us!</p>



<p>Reference Links</p>



<p>Kmesh Release v1.1.0Ôºàhttps://github.com/kmesh-net/kmesh/releases/tag/v1.1.0Ôºâ</p>



<p>Kmesh GitHubÔºàhttps://github.com/kmesh-net/kmeshÔºâ</p>



<p>Kmesh WebsiteÔºàhttps://kmesh.net/Ôºâ</p>
]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>OpenYurt Becomes a CNCF Incubating Project</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/07/02/openyurt-becomes-a-cncf-incubating-project/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[OpenYurt Project Maintainers]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Wed, 02 Jul 2025 13:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=136537</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[The Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) Technical Oversight Committee (TOC) has voted to accept OpenYurt as an incubating project. OpenYurt joins a growing ecosystem of technologies tackling real-world challenges at the edge of cloud-native infrastructure. What...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>The Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) Technical Oversight Committee (TOC) has voted to accept <strong>OpenYurt</strong> as an incubating project. OpenYurt joins a growing ecosystem of technologies tackling real-world challenges at the edge of cloud-native infrastructure.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>What is OpenYurt?</strong></h3>



<p>OpenYurt is a Kubernetes-native platform purpose-built for <strong>cloud-edge orchestration</strong>. Originally open-sourced by <strong>Alibaba Cloud in May 2020</strong>, OpenYurt enables developers and operators to manage edge applications with the same consistency and experience as cloud-based deployments. It addresses common challenges including:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Disconnected or unreliable cloud-edge networking</li>



<li>Edge autonomy</li>



<li>Region-aware deployment</li>



<li>Edge device management</li>
</ul>



<p>Most importantly, OpenYurt retains full compatibility with Kubernetes APIs, is vendor agnostic, and emphasizes simplicity and usability.</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Key Milestones and Ecosystem Growth</strong></h3>



<p>Since joining the CNCF Sandbox in <strong>September 2020</strong>, OpenYurt has steadily matured:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>The number of maintainers has expanded from 3 to 9, representing organizations like <strong>Microsoft, Alibaba, VMware, Intel, Inspur, Sangfor, Tongji University</strong>, and independent contributors.</li>



<li>A growing<a href="https://github.com/openyurtio/openyurt/blob/master/ADOPTERS.md"> ADOPTERS.md</a> file highlights real-world use in production and development.</li>



<li>Significant features have been added, including:
<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li><strong>Device Management</strong></li>



<li><strong>Multi-region Resource and Workload Management</strong></li>



<li><strong>Node Pool Traffic Closure</strong></li>



<li><strong>Cross-region Communication</strong></li>



<li><strong>Traffic Replication at the Node/Pool level</strong></li>
</ul>
</li>



<li>Enhancements to <strong>node autonomy</strong>, deployment tooling, community documentation, and user interface have made the platform more accessible and production-ready.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Integrations Across the Cloud Native Landscape</strong></h3>



<p>OpenYurt connects seamlessly with many CNCF projects, including:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li><strong>Kubernetes</strong> ‚Äì the foundation of OpenYurt&#8217;s orchestration model</li>



<li><strong>Helm</strong> ‚Äì for deploying cloud controllers</li>



<li><strong>WasmEdge</strong> ‚Äì enabling lightweight workloads via WebAssembly</li>



<li><strong>KinD</strong> ‚Äì for local testing and GitHub Actions integration</li>



<li><strong>Prometheus</strong> ‚Äì for metrics collection and observability</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Technical Components</strong></h3>



<p>OpenYurt‚Äôs architecture includes several key modules:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li><strong>Yurt-Manager</strong>: A set of controllers and webhooks that bring cloud-edge coordination to Kubernetes, including workload updates and multi-region management.</li>



<li><strong>YurtHub</strong>: A sidecar on edge nodes that ensures autonomy and efficient communication, even in disconnected scenarios.</li>



<li><strong>Raven</strong>: A project that enables cross-region networking and pod-to-pod communication in distributed environments.</li>



<li><strong>Yurt-IoT-Dock</strong>: An integration layer with IoT platforms like EdgeX Foundry to support declarative device management.</li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Community Highlights</strong></h3>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li><strong>1.8k GitHub Stars</strong></li>



<li><strong>170 contributors</strong> across organizations and geographies</li>



<li><strong>1581 pull requests and 785 issues</strong> closed</li>



<li><strong>33 releases</strong>, including the stable <strong>v1.0 in September 2022</strong></li>
</ul>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Maintainer Perspective</strong></h3>



<p>&#8220;It has evolved into a Cloud-to-Edge framework with beautiful architecture to facilitate efficient application construction, deployment, and scaling. We‚Äôve seen adoption from startups to major carriers and formed a vibrant, fast-moving community. I‚Äôm excited to see OpenYurt grow as a foundation for the next wave of AI-powered cloud-edge applications.&#8221;</p>



<p>‚Äî <strong>Shaoqiang Chen</strong>, Maintainer, OpenYurt</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>From the TOC</strong></h3>



<p>&#8220;OpenYurt fits well in the cloud native landscape, adding critical capabilities in edge environments like IoT and industrial automation. Its approach of extending‚Äîrather than replacing‚ÄîKubernetes makes it accessible and practical for real-world deployment. I‚Äôm excited to support its continued growth.&#8221;</p>



<p>‚Äî <em>CNCF TOC Sponsor</em></p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading"><strong>Looking Ahead</strong></h3>



<p><strong>OpenYurt‚Äôs roadmap for 2025</strong> includes:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Support for Kubernetes v1.32</li>



<li>Network diagnostics and request multiplexing across node pools</li>



<li>Merging the Raven networking layer into the core repository</li>



<li>Support for <strong>EdgeX v4.0</strong> and scalable on-prem Kubernetes deployment</li>
</ul>



<p>As a CNCF incubating project, OpenYurt now joins technologies like <strong>OpenTelemetry, KubeVirt, Knative, Kyverno, cert-manager</strong>, and many others solving critical challenges across cloud native infrastructure.</p>



<p>We look forward to seeing how OpenYurt continues to evolve the edge computing landscape with the backing of the CNCF community.</p>



<p>Learn more: https://www.cncf.io/projects/openyurt</p>
]]></content:encoded>
					
		
		
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Cloud Native Glossary ‚Äî The Vietnamese Version is Live!</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/06/26/cloud-native-glossary-the-vietnamese-version-is-live/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Cloud Native Glossary Vietnamese Localization Team]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 Jun 2025 04:27:00 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=134175</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[The Cloud Native Glossary is a project that aims to define cloud native concepts in clear and simple language, making them accessible to anyone without requiring any previous technical knowledge. This project thrives on open contributions...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>The <a href="https://glossary.cncf.io/">Cloud Native Glossary</a> is a project that aims to define cloud native concepts in clear and simple language, making them accessible to anyone without requiring any previous technical knowledge. This project thrives on <a href="https://github.com/cncf/glossary">open contributions</a> from a diverse community of contributors and is currently maintained by <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/seokho-son/">Seokho Son</a>, <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/noah-ispas-0665b42a/">Noah Ispas</a>, <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/jihoon-seo/">Jihoon Seo</a>, <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/nate-double-u/">Nate W.</a>, and <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/junya-okabe/">Junya Okabe</a>.&nbsp;</p>



<p>As you may know we are actively localizing the English version of the Glossary into as many languages as possible. This time, we are excited to announce the inclusion of <a href="https://glossary.cncf.io/vi/">Vietnamese localization</a>. We are thrilled to share this milestone with you. Now, let‚Äôs meet the Vietnamese team and contributors who made this possible.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">About Vietnamese&nbsp; and Vietnamese in the Glossary</h2>



<p>Vietnamese is the official language of Vietnam, spoken by over 95 million people worldwide. It uses the Latin-based Qu·ªëc Ng·ªØ script and follows a Subject-Verb-Object (SVO) structure similar to English, which offers certain advantages for translation.</p>



<p>However, translating cloud native technical concepts into Vietnamese in a way that is academically accurate, easy to understand, and natural-sounding is a major challenge. The team spent several months discussing, researching, and cross-referencing to select the most appropriate terminology, ensuring consistency and high quality throughout the glossary. Dozens of core glossary entries have already been localized, and the work continues with active community involvement.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Why Vietnamese in the Glossary Matters</h2>



<p>Although the Cloud Native Glossary is an invaluable resource, its accessibility for the Vietnamese community has long been hindered by language barriers. Many developers, students, and technology enthusiasts in Vietnam have found it challenging to fully grasp complex cloud native concepts due to the lack of localized materials.</p>



<p>The release of the Vietnamese version addresses this challenge directly. By breaking down linguistic obstacles, it enables a wider range of users in Vietnam‚Äîwhether they are just beginning their cloud journey or are already working professionals‚Äîto better access and understand foundational cloud native concepts.</p>



<p>Beyond accessibility, the localized Glossary promotes learning and real-world application. It supports education, research, and the implementation of cloud native technologies in Vietnam, ultimately helping to strengthen the skill set and global competitiveness of the local IT workforce.</p>



<p>Additionally, this effort plays a key role in building a more cohesive and collaborative Vietnamese cloud native community. By standardizing technical terminology, it creates a shared language that enhances communication, knowledge sharing, and mutual support among developers and professionals.</p>



<p>Finally, the Vietnamese Glossary encourages greater participation in the global open-source movement. With clearer understanding and more confidence, Vietnamese contributors are better equipped to join and contribute to international projects‚Äîstarting with the Glossary itself.</p>



<p>We strongly believe that making technical knowledge available in the native language is not just about translation‚Äîit‚Äôs about empowerment. It brings technology closer to the people and lays the foundation for new innovations and opportunities within Vietnam‚Äôs evolving tech landscape.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Challenges and Lessons Learned&nbsp;</h2>



<p>The process of localizing the Cloud Native Glossary into Vietnamese has been a challenging yet deeply rewarding journey. One of the most significant obstacles the team faced was the standardization of technical terminology. Since many cloud native concepts are still relatively new in the Vietnamese context, there were no widely accepted translations. To address this, the team engaged in extensive discussions, consulted domain experts, and incorporated feedback from the broader community to determine the most suitable terms. In certain cases, this involved retaining English terms accompanied by contextual explanations or coining new, descriptive phrases that would be intuitive for native speakers.</p>



<p>Another important challenge was ensuring clarity and natural phrasing throughout the translation; as translating complex definitions goes far beyond word-for-word conversion‚Äîit requires accurately capturing meaning while preserving coherence, readability, and a natural tone in Vietnamese. This was especially critical when working with abstract or technical concepts that might not yet exist in everyday language.</p>



<p>The team also had to navigate coordination and synchronization across multiple contributors working from different time zones. This required well-defined workflows, effective communication, and the use of collaborative tools to maintain consistency across the entire glossary. Ensuring that all translated entries aligned in tone, terminology, and formatting took careful planning and collaboration.</p>



<p>Moreover, as a community-led initiative, the project demanded significant time, patience, and commitment from each volunteer. Balancing personal and professional responsibilities while contributing to a shared mission was not easy, but every member showed remarkable dedication.</p>



<p>Through this experience, the team realized that having a style guide and a shared term base from the beginning was essential. They also saw firsthand how community feedback played a vital role in improving the quality of the work. Most importantly, it became clear that collaboration, openness, and a willingness to learn were the driving forces that helped the team overcome challenges and achieve success together.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">How to Get Involved</h2>



<p>We always welcome new contributions from the community! Participating in the Cloud Native Glossary project is a great opportunity for you to both learn and give back to a global initiative.</p>



<p>By taking part in the translation and review process, you‚Äôll gain valuable insights and develop a deeper understanding of cloud native technologies. It‚Äôs a hands-on learning experience that allows you to absorb knowledge while also helping to make it more accessible to others.</p>



<p>The project also offers a chance to expand your professional network. You‚Äôll connect with like-minded individuals and industry experts from around the world, opening the door to potential collaboration and shared learning.</p>



<p>Equally important, your involvement is a meaningful way to contribute to the Vietnamese tech community. By helping to localize the Glossary, you are playing a part in making cloud native concepts more understandable and approachable for everyone.</p>



<p>You don‚Äôt need to be a seasoned cloud native expert to join. If you are passionate, have a good command of English, and are eager to contribute, you can make a real impact.</p>



<p>Join us on the CNCF Slack channel #glossary-localization-vietnamese or visit the project‚Äôs <a href="https://github.com/cncf/glossary"><em>Github</em></a> page for more details.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Final Thoughts</h2>



<p>The launch of the Vietnamese version of the Cloud Native Glossary is a testament to the power of community and the open-source spirit. We hope this will be a useful reference and a starting point for many new initiatives in the Vietnamese cloud native community.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Meet the Vietnamese Team and Contributors</h2>



<p>The following is a list of key contributors to the initial release of the Vietnamese in the Cloud Native Glossary.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/ntheanh201/"><strong>The Anh Nguyen</strong></a>: The Anh is a DevOps Engineer at Viettel Networks and an enthusiastic open source advocate, deeply engaged in Kubernetes and Cloud Native technologies. Holding multiple Kubernetes certifications, he is passionate about contributing to the Cloud Native ecosystem. He actively contributes to the Cloud Native Glossary and the Kubernetes website, sharing his technical expertise through open source contributions.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/tienthuan05082002/"><strong>Thuan Pham Tien</strong></a>: Thuan Pham Tien is a DevOps and SRE engineer at MinhPhuc Transformation. He has a Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA) certificate and loves working with Kubernetes and Cloud Native tools. Thuan supports open source projects and helps with the Vietnamese translation of the Cloud Native Glossary, aiming to make tech more accessible for the local community.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/huannd2301/"><strong>Huan Nguyen Danh</strong></a><strong> </strong>Huan Nguyen Danh is a Backend Engineer at MinhPhuc Transformation, specializing in Golang. He actively contributes to open-source projects and supports the Vietnamese translation of the Cloud Native Glossary. His goal is to make modern technologies more accessible to the local community and help bridge the gap between global innovation and local adoption.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/nguyenphuongthao0/"><strong>Phuong Thao Nguyen</strong></a>: Phuong Thao (Thaomike) ‚Äî a passionate Full-Stack Developer currently working at VFast Soft Company. With strong skills in both frontend and backend development, she&#8217;s now expanding her horizons into the world of DevOps and cloud technologies. Eager to deepen her understanding of the cloud native ecosystem, Thaomike actively contributes to the Vietnamese localization of the Cloud Native Glossary. Through this meaningful work, she not only supports the local tech community but also gains valuable insights into the vast and fascinating realm of cloud native computing.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/trieungoctam/"><strong>Ngoc Tam Trieu</strong></a>: Ngoc Tam is a student at the Posts and Telecommunications Institute of Technology and an AI engineer at Icetea Labs. His work focuses on chatbot systems, AI Agents, and integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) into practical applications. He is also a contributor to the Vietnamese localization of the Cloud Native Glossary, supporting efforts to make foundational cloud native concepts more accessible to the local tech community.</p>



<p>__________________________________________________________________</p>

<h2 class="wp-block-heading">L·ªùi k·∫øt</h2>



<p>Vi·ªác ra m·∫Øt phi√™n b·∫£n ti·∫øng Vi·ªát c·ªßa Cloud Native Glossary l√† minh ch·ª©ng r√µ r√†ng cho s·ª©c m·∫°nh c·ªßa c·ªông ƒë·ªìng v√† tinh th·∫ßn m√£ ngu·ªìn m·ªü. Ch√∫ng t√¥i hy v·ªçng r·∫±ng t√†i li·ªáu n√†y s·∫Ω tr·ªü th√†nh m·ªôt ngu·ªìn tham kh·∫£o h·ªØu √≠ch v√† l√† b∆∞·ªõc kh·ªüi ƒë·∫ßu cho nhi·ªÅu s√°ng ki·∫øn ƒë·∫ßy c·∫£m h·ª©ng trong c·ªông ƒë·ªìng Cloud Native Vi·ªát Nam.</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">G·∫∑p g·ª° ƒë·ªôi ng≈© Vi·ªát Nam v√† c√°c c·ªông t√°c vi√™n</h2>



<p>D∆∞·ªõi ƒë√¢y l√† danh s√°ch c√°c c·ªông t√°c vi√™n ch√≠nh ƒë√£ ƒë√≥ng g√≥p v√†o phi√™n b·∫£n ti·∫øng Vi·ªát ƒë·∫ßu ti√™n c·ªßa Cloud Native Glossary.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/ntheanh201/"><strong>The Anh Nguyen</strong></a>: Th·∫ø Anh l√† K·ªπ s∆∞ DevOps t·∫°i Viettel Networks v√† l√† m·ªôt ng∆∞·ªùi ƒëam m√™ m√£ ngu·ªìn m·ªü, c√≥ s·ª± quan t√¢m s√¢u s·∫Øc ƒë·∫øn Kubernetes v√† c√°c c√¥ng ngh·ªá Cloud Native. Anh s·ªü h·ªØu nhi·ªÅu ch·ª©ng ch·ªâ Kubernetes v√† lu√¥n nhi·ªát huy·∫øt ƒë√≥ng g√≥p cho h·ªá sinh th√°i Cloud Native. Th·∫ø Anh t√≠ch c·ª±c tham gia ƒë√≥ng g√≥p cho Cloud Native Glossary v√† trang web Kubernetes, chia s·∫ª ki·∫øn th·ª©c chuy√™n m√¥n th√¥ng qua c√°c ƒë√≥ng g√≥p m√£ ngu·ªìn m·ªü.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/tienthuan05082002/"><strong>Thuan Pham Tien</strong></a>: Ph·∫°m Ti·∫øn Thu·∫≠n l√† K·ªπ s∆∞ DevOps ki√™m SRE t·∫°i Minh Ph√∫c Transformation. Thu·∫≠n s·ªü h·ªØu ch·ª©ng ch·ªâ Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA) v√† c√≥ ni·ªÅm y√™u th√≠ch ƒë·∫∑c bi·ªát v·ªõi Kubernetes v√† c√°c c√¥ng c·ª• Cloud Native. Thu·∫≠n th∆∞·ªùng xuy√™n h·ªó tr·ª£ c√°c d·ª± √°n m√£ ngu·ªìn m·ªü v√† ƒë√≥ng g√≥p v√†o b·∫£n d·ªãch ti·∫øng Vi·ªát c·ªßa Cloud Native Glossary, v·ªõi m·ª•c ti√™u gi√∫p c√¥ng ngh·ªá tr·ªü n√™n d·ªÖ ti·∫øp c·∫≠n h∆°n v·ªõi c·ªông ƒë·ªìng trong n∆∞·ªõc.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/huannd2301/"><strong>Huan Nguyen Danh</strong></a><strong> </strong>Nguy·ªÖn Danh Hu·∫•n l√† K·ªπ s∆∞ Backend t·∫°i Minh Ph√∫c Transformation, chuy√™n v·ªÅ Golang. Hu·∫•n t√≠ch c·ª±c tham gia c√°c d·ª± √°n m√£ ngu·ªìn m·ªü v√† h·ªó tr·ª£ b·∫£n d·ªãch ti·∫øng Vi·ªát c·ªßa Cloud Native Glossary. M·ª•c ti√™u c·ªßa Hu·∫•n l√† gi√∫p c√°c c√¥ng ngh·ªá hi·ªán ƒë·∫°i ƒë·∫øn g·∫ßn h∆°n v·ªõi c·ªông ƒë·ªìng trong n∆∞·ªõc v√† thu h·∫πp kho·∫£ng c√°ch gi·ªØa ƒë·ªïi m·ªõi to√†n c·∫ßu v√† ·ª©ng d·ª•ng th·ª±c t·∫ø t·∫°i Vi·ªát Nam.</p>



<p><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/nguyenphuongthao0/"><strong>Phuong Thao Nguyen</strong></a>: Ph∆∞∆°ng Th·∫£o (Thaomike) l√† m·ªôt L·∫≠p tr√¨nh vi√™n Full-Stack ƒëang l√†m vi·ªác t·∫°i c√¥ng ty VFast Soft. V·ªõi n·ªÅn t·∫£ng k·ªπ nƒÉng v·ªØng ch·∫Øc ·ªü c·∫£ frontend l·∫´n backend, Th·∫£o hi·ªán ƒëang m·ªü r·ªông ki·∫øn th·ª©c sang lƒ©nh v·ª±c DevOps v√† c√°c c√¥ng ngh·ªá ƒëi·ªán to√°n ƒë√°m m√¢y. Thaomike t√≠ch c·ª±c tham gia b·∫£n ƒë·ªãa h√≥a Cloud Native Glossary sang ti·∫øng Vi·ªát. Th√¥ng qua ho·∫°t ƒë·ªông n√†y, Th·∫£o kh√¥ng ch·ªâ ƒë√≥ng g√≥p cho c·ªông ƒë·ªìng c√¥ng ngh·ªá trong n∆∞·ªõc m√† c√≤n t√≠ch l≈©y th√™m nhi·ªÅu hi·ªÉu bi·∫øt gi√° tr·ªã v·ªÅ th·∫ø gi·ªõi Cloud Native r·ªông l·ªõn v√† ƒë·∫ßy ti·ªÅm nƒÉng.<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/trieungoctam/"><strong>Ngoc Tam Trieu</strong></a>: Ng·ªçc T√¢m l√† sinh vi√™n t·∫°i H·ªçc vi·ªán C√¥ng ngh·ªá B∆∞u ch√≠nh Vi·ªÖn th√¥ng v√† l√† k·ªπ s∆∞ AI t·∫°i Icetea Labs. C√¥ng vi·ªác c·ªßa anh t·∫≠p trung v√†o h·ªá th·ªëng chatbot, AI Agent v√† t√≠ch h·ª£p c√°c M√¥ h√¨nh Ng√¥n ng·ªØ L·ªõn (LLM) v√†o c√°c ·ª©ng d·ª•ng th·ª±c ti·ªÖn. T√¢m c≈©ng l√† m·ªôt trong nh·ªØng ng∆∞·ªùi ƒë√≥ng g√≥p cho b·∫£n d·ªãch ti·∫øng Vi·ªát c·ªßa Cloud Native Glossary, g√≥p ph·∫ßn gi√∫p c·ªông ƒë·ªìng c√¥ng ngh·ªá trong n∆∞·ªõc d·ªÖ d√†ng ti·∫øp c·∫≠n h∆°n v·ªõi c√°c kh√°i ni·ªám n·ªÅn t·∫£ng c·ªßa Cloud Native.</p>
]]></content:encoded>
					
		
		
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Cloud Native App Local Development Made Easy with Microcks and Dapr</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/06/25/cloud-native-app-local-development-made-easy-with-microcks-and-dapr/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Mauricio Salatino and Laurent Broudoux]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Jun 2025 23:56:04 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=135050</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[Cloud native application development can be intimidating sometimes! Architecting distributed applications that need to access and connect to complex infrastructure requires developers to learn different technologies and cloud services, which slows down their development tasks. It...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>Cloud native application development can be intimidating sometimes! Architecting distributed applications that need to access and connect to complex infrastructure requires developers to learn different technologies and cloud services, which slows down their development tasks. It does get more challenging if developers need to deploy, debug, and test their applications on a <a href="https://kubernetes.io">Kubernetes</a> cluster, as now they need to master not only Kubernetes but also how to containerize and distribute their applications. On the testing front, if your applications are composed of multiple services, it becomes challenging to start them all for development and testing scenarios. Wouldn‚Äôt it be great if we could simplify these complexities while promoting best practices, so applications run smoothly on our Kubernetes clusters?&nbsp;</p>



<p>In this blog post, we will look at how two CNCF projects can help us to simplify cloud native development and testing, both on Kubernetes and outside Kubernetes clusters. We will start by looking at how <a href="https://dapr.io">Dapr</a>, a graduated <a href="https://cncf.io">CNCF</a> project, decouples the access to complex infrastructure from application code by giving application developers APIs that promote best practices and abstract away cloud services and complex infrastructure that platform teams can configure.&nbsp;</p>



<p>When adding extensions to our Kubernetes clusters this can affect how applications are run and behave, pushing development teams to figure out how to replicate these setups for development tasks. How do we enable developers&#8217; productivity (and joy!) without running their applications on Kubernetes clusters? That&#8217;s where <a href="https://microcks.io">Microcks</a>, a sandbox CNCF project, shines. It eases the pain of setting up complex environments by providing mocks for your dependencies.</p>



<p>This post details our experiment introducing Microcks into the famous Dapr <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/salaboy/">Salaboy</a>&#8216;s <a href="https://github.com/salaboy/pizza">pizza demo application</a> (see <a href="https://github.com/salaboy/pizza">https://github.com/salaboy/pizza</a>). You&#8217;ll learn how to use Microcks with Dapr for an unprecedented developer experience of a lightweight environment that allows shifting left the detection of most integration issues upfront!</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXeLjl0EVuYMrK1VDxUw79fWX5eHpSxYHE4w-jVX46G5cXZCfxXCFY2H2U3lttpQ7YjswdAdkKgQvKMuJH_XW2oFLrSMWcYICjXtJ_Dx2Y14qB73BpguiYjIJo-B-umSqXPnhu1j?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image expression of old Vespa with a side car as Dapr + Microcks: Sidecars, Mocks and Contract Testing For The Win!"/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><a href="https://unsplash.com/photos/green-and-white-motor-scooter-parked-on-sidewalk-during-daytime-_Vq_W4tg-2U"><em>Dapr + Microcks: Sidecars, Mocks and Contract Testing For The Win!</em></a></p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Application Overview</h2>



<p>The Pizza Store application simulates placing a Pizza Order that different services will process. The application is composed of the `Store` Service, which serves as the front end and back end for placing the order. The order is sent to the `Kitchen` Service for preparation, and once it is ready to be delivered, the `Delivery` Service takes it to your door. For a full description of synchronous and asynchronous flows, I encourage you to look at the <a href="https://github.com/salaboy/pizza/blob/main/README.md">README</a>.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXdHeU_N4KDqZ0bF3t_IcnN6MK6WOHlTCUREOFeu5QlhHkEWdfCDRXP-3jcFUljvhyKrGTB9SccfDxNx6zh8_gyGVGI9RY48ABdJxmeyvN6vIQzRc2TyIwfI8RczhLVE3A3OJOkjsQ?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of The Pizza Application Overview"/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>The Pizza Application Overview</em></p>



<p>Adding <a href="https://dapr.io">Dapr</a> to this application helps developers abstract complex concerns about infrastructure, service-to-service communications, security, observability, and resiliency while simplifying the application logic. For each Dapr-enabled service, Dapr injects a sidecar that exposes application-level APIs when running on a Kubernetes cluster. The Dapr sidecar is now responsible for understanding how to route requests across services, but also provides access to application dependencies such as Kafka, a message broker, without the need to add any dependency to the application code.&nbsp;</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXdKWT_tYMpJLSFMHIeybSaUImKtvQFHK7xhYaupaL2TY2V5y1HH43x0TfxjiguvQrVWryaQkzSX1E6ieq_4xSPilaCob22f18kmeQqDJuCPDDzLTa_qtNenki7bDJk2e1_teSUVJA?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of The Pizza Application implemented with Dap on Kubernetes"/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>The Pizza Application implemented with Dapr on Kubernetes</em></p>



<p>The `Store`, `Kitchen`, and `Delivery` services can now rely on the Dapr APIs to implement common distributed application logic from any programming language, reusing hundreds of implementations, allowing them to move their applications across different environments without changing, repackaging, or re-releasing their source code. Check the <a href="https://docs.dapr.io/concepts/overview/">Dapr official documentation</a> page for a full list of APIs and implementations.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXd59UTvVRx4zN1kz0b_wN2LICRS-jAqD7epJ6mHsl1fUXJhSM7CgX3QYTICYVz3eOe98-JarHz9d9Wo461K7QrqlILBXyOmFYNIwr0_HO9SU46elGC6Xa3fLT5UytQnqrCatzClmw?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of Dapr APIs and implementations."/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>Caption needed</em></p>



<p>But as mentioned before, working on Kubernetes with projects like Dapr, which rely on the sidecar pattern, can complicate local development and testing. So, let‚Äôs take a quick look at some of the challenges that developers will face when working with these distributed applications.&nbsp;</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Challenges</h3>



<p>Distributed applications, like the Pizza Store, present challenges for developers in fixing bugs or adding new features to the application services:</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>To confidently test a change, all components should be present in the environment. Developers must master tasks such as creating a Kubernetes cluster, installing Dapr, and containerizing their services. Running all these components might require a <strong>fair amount of resources</strong>!</li>



<li>To test any changes to the services, all dependencies must be built and run locally. Depending on your technology stack&#8217;s diversity, this may require <strong>advanced knowledge</strong>!¬†</li>



<li>May you choose not to deploy everything; you expose yourself to <strong>integration issues</strong>. Deploying everything still exposes you to <strong>configuration drift risks</strong>!</li>
</ul>



<p>All those concerns and challenges require teams to spend time to mitigate them, slowing down the development&#8217;s feedback loop, and finally <strong>impacting developers‚Äô velocity</strong>!</p>



<h3 class="wp-block-heading">Team scopes &amp; responsibilities</h3>



<p>For this example, imagine that a different team of developers is responsible for each of the application‚Äôs services. As service owners, each team is interested in improving the service with consistent interfaces that other services can rely on‚Äîits synchronous and asynchronous APIs.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Let‚Äôs look at the `Store` Service. We will notice that the team is responsible for exposing one REST API endpoint for placing pizza orders and creating two downstream calls to the `Kitchen` and `Delivery` Services to process the order.&nbsp;</p>



<p>This means that the team responsible for the `Store` Service needs both the `Kitchen` and `Delivery` Services to validate that their changes will not break other services. One good practice to codify these contracts is to use standard specifications like <a href="https://www.openapis.org/">OpenAPI</a> and <a href="https://www.asyncapi.com/en">AsyncAPI</a> to describe those interactions.&nbsp;</p>



<p>If we add Dapr to the mix, developers in charge of testing the Store Service need to not only set up the downstream services but also their Dapr configurations.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXe_mPF8rS1CFOhk1sSFGnRT3M7c7ySdrxBaXWgde2ZgabMkcCiFUF6oY1YbuQsgZzduhhRpIYIUpXacVehYklVigH74H2c8rmAfB6NQa48ksbamXI42ChQpWbgWmU39FDc3B36ReQ?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of downstream services and their Dapr configurations."/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>Caption needed</em></p>



<p>Before jumping into how <a href="https://microcks.io">Microcks</a> can help us here, let‚Äôs look at the `Kitchen` Service, which presents a different scenario.&nbsp;</p>



<p>The `Kitchen` Service is in charge of preparing the order and notifying the store asynchronously about its progress. The application architect has decided to use Kafka as transport for exchanging messages across applications; hence, every time the `Kitchen` wants to notify the store about progress, a new Kafka message is placed in a topic.&nbsp;</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXdG2xFVtj3H1SL4T6GUpK6cn0ssB9Qmam4Cu_8qlRyQ5_PmKgrJ25gFQZ5P8gMbfWOj6_RLDw4_OddwAVf0GKARwuNBAh9ZMN8-bTgcmcbEPui7aMYL_E5IrBYrEa8m0gGF-uXWNw?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of the `Kitchen` notifying the store about progress, and how a new Kafka message is placed in a topic.¬†"/></figure>



<p>&gt; By using Dapr PubSub APIs, the Kitchen Service team doesn‚Äôt need to worry about Kafka at all; they just use the Dapr PubSub API (`publishEvent(event)`) to emit an event about the pizza preparation progress.&nbsp;</p>



<p>&gt; The team has chosen a Kafka Topic as the medium from which consumers can get messages (whether using Dapr or not), ensuring that this component receives correctly formed messages, which is undoubtedly part of the owner&#8217;s contract promise.&nbsp;</p>



<p>For the `Store` and `Kitchen` services, application developers need downstream services and application dependencies such as Kafka to validate changes. Using the services contracts, their configurations, and dependencies, we can define each of these services&#8217; boundaries. Relying on these service boundaries and contracts, we can use Microcks to:&nbsp;</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Build simulations of your dependencies from their contracts to allow each team to work in isolation‚Äîthis is the mocking part.</li>



<li>Build complete test suites from your contracts to allow you to verify that you‚Äôre not drifting from your service‚Äôs contract‚Äîthis is the testing part.</li>
</ul>



<p>This approach will allow us to define isolated units to which we will apply our Dapr + Microcks combo. But enough theory! Now, let&#8217;s dive in the details!</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Simplifying distributed application testing experience with Microcks</h2>



<p>How can <a href="https://microcks.io">Microcks</a> help to locally develop and test complex distributed Dapr-enabled applications without pushing developers to learn about Kubernetes?&nbsp;</p>



<p>Given the `Store` Service component boundaries, we&#8217;ll achieve this local configuration where the Dapr sidecar will be started right beside the service, and Microcks will simulate the `Kitchen` and `Delivery` Service components for both pub/sub and service invocations interactions:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXenqNLPm6cBl1Y-GvO4AYpg5FRC7MOHP-fvXtKAFi2EtrUqfPDwaXY-VPQoIoGf1lwxZFFbtrHdGHSjxTHLJq79vG9xLgSmB0W_1NNpvjfCARyQ-lLZ-dw1l4lXPIj9GEIOXXBX9g?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of achieved local configuration where the Dapr sidecar will be started right beside the service, and Microcks will simulate the `Kitchen` and `Delivery` Service components for both pub/sub and service invocations interactions:"/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>Caption needed</em></p>



<p>Microcks creates mocks for Kitchen and Delivery Services,&nbsp; based on their contracts, with associated endpoints to make them available for the Store Service to run its tests. Microcks also simulates sending messages to Kafka, so the application can validate its behaviour.&nbsp;</p>



<p>For this example, the configuration to create these tests includes:&nbsp;</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>A reference to the contracts for the Kitchen and Delivery Services REST APIs (OpenAPI),</li>



<li>A reference to the AsyncAPI contract used to exchange messages via Kafka,</li>



<li>The configuration needed to connect the Microcks simulations of Kitchen and Delivery Service contracts and Dapr to Kafka,</li>
</ul>



<p>Let‚Äôs see how the components can be wired together from the `Store` Service team&#8217;s perspective.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXe04z9-WEMGVWD7FGMo5jnYAQY5BnuK-h6m1hMHemLhqc7h2rpnifTXKahU2JzPSq82T7pu_otoiu-f9daZTE9g8V7C18_PUQXjh4V8qkqZoSTA7kta2CoRnsj1Yfqx8wqzt9EEPw?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image on how components can be wired together from the `Store` Service team's perspective."/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>Microcks uses service contracts to simulate dependency endpoints</em></p>



<p>As we can see in the diagram, instead of starting the `Kitchen` and `Delivery` Services, we rely on Microcks to run a simulation of these services based on their OpenAPI contracts. Notice that all service-to-service communications will happen via the Dapr sidecars, leveraging in this way resiliency, security, and observability features, but this requires us to set up Dapr sidecars also for the mocks.&nbsp;</p>



<p>For testing the synchronous interactions across systems, this setup enables the team working on the `Store` Service to make progress without waiting on the `Kitchen` and `Delivery` Services teams. As long as they keep their contract in sync, the `Store` Service team can be confident that their changes are not breaking other services.&nbsp;</p>



<p>For asynchronous interactions, the team can rely on <a href="https://asyncapi.com">AsyncAPI</a> definitions to validate that the messages exchanged follow a previously defined contract.&nbsp;</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXeWjnq1Une1NqjnbuzA9xfnyIC4fxEXBdymAckC02xEhhShJcPuTlk0DbaC4xwv2WairE0Ysbf_X1jja63q8v_QXvE6aXkM5kq5kuSqaehgYw9ys5pJur1SY7GiP0J114TB-ijo?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of Microcks using event contracts to simulate event producers."/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>Microcks uses event contracts to simulate event producers</em></p>



<p>Microcks can simulate message producers and deliver to Kafka following the Async APIs contracts of these services. The `Store` Service can test the expected behavior when receiving async messages via Dapr Subscriptions.&nbsp;</p>



<p>With this configuration, teams have a full working application in which the Dapr container acts like it‚Äôs connected to real endpoints. They can make progress using a contract-first approach, where Microcks provides all the simulations from the provided contracts. This configuration is <strong>lightweight</strong>, <strong>fast to start</strong>, and <strong>doesn‚Äôt require knowledge</strong> of the other components&#8217; technologies. However, all this wiring may need to be streamlined. That‚Äôs where Platform Engineers can help!&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">What does this mean for Platform Engineers?&nbsp;&nbsp;</h2>



<p>As mentioned in the previous section, we need contracts, sidecars, simulation servers, and a bunch of configuration files to connect all the required components for these tests. To build this example, we focused on two key aspects:&nbsp;</p>



<ul class="wp-block-list">
<li>Local development experience</li>



<li>Relied on¬† containers to create libraries of reproducible configurations and scenarios that development teams can use to test their services</li>
</ul>



<p>We wanted to ensure that developers could run the application locally for development purposes and run tests without running inside Kubernetes. To achieve this, we used <a href="https://testcontainers.com/">Testcontainers</a>, a library that allows us to configure how containers are started and wired up together to create the previously described scenarios.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Writing these scenarios was straightforward, as both projects (Dapr and Microcks) integrate with <a href="https://testcontainers.com">Testcontainers</a> (now part of Docker).&nbsp;</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image"><img decoding="async" src="https://lh7-rt.googleusercontent.com/docsz/AD_4nXeSA-xWtHqvRWkYQrGpIeW21A4E5-APqTCKH1tIbqCPh18jIv7V8pT14ezW00tdZhaknr_oIiGFUuDssBHmvhE15Hx-stglfDF3mc-ti1SMdOC7kumuGk7JEhWASRlBjTcpmUxrYw?key=gWi1IFxtgJlqTPXziapBE4fr" alt="Image of Dapr + Microcks for lightweight dependency simulations."/></figure>



<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>Dapr + Microcks for lightweight dependency simulations</em></p>



<p>With these configurations, platform engineering teams can create libraries that teams can use to avoid recreating these configurations in each service. Facilitating the initial wiring of all these components and contracts to other teams enables developers to focus on writing tests instead of figuring out how all these pieces fit together.&nbsp;</p>



<p>Using these tools also enables developers to run, debug, and test without running a local Kubernetes cluster, which further reduces the cognitive load imposed on developers.&nbsp;</p>



<p>&gt; If you are wondering if this approach of using simulations also makes sense on Kubernetes, for example, to lower the cost of building environments, then Microcks has your back! Many Microcks adopters are also using it through its <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D7Jsr7-R3p8">GitOps-compliant Operator</a> to simulate third-party dependencies like CRM or Payment providers on their central environments!</p>



<p>We believe that the techniques and approach that we have taken to combine Dapr and Microcks can be leveraged by multiple projects in the CNCF, as this example demonstrates how developers can keep using the tools that they are comfortable with, instead of spending time trying to figure out how other tools work.&nbsp;</p>



<h2 class="wp-block-heading">Wrap-up</h2>



<p>Combining <a href="https://dapr.io">Dapr</a> and <a href="https://microcks.io">Microcks</a> offers a powerful solution for simplifying cloud-native application development. By leveraging Dapr&#8217;s sidecar architecture for seamless service sync and async communications and Microcks for mocking dependencies and testing, developers can efficiently simulate complex distributed systems without the need to deploy every service to a Kubernetes cluster.&nbsp;</p>



<p>This approach streamlines the development process, accelerates feedback loops, and helps detect integration issues early, significantly improving productivity and confidence in application reliability. Whether you&#8217;re mocking APIs or testing event-driven workflows, this combination provides a lightweight, quick-to-set-up, and highly effective development environment that allows teams to focus more on building features and less on managing infrastructure.<br>If you want to learn more about Dapr or Microcks, or how to combine them, you can check out the&nbsp; <a href="https://dapr.io">Dapr Website</a> and the&nbsp; <a href="https://microcks.io">Microcks Website</a>; or join their vibrant communities on both the <a href="http://bit.ly//dapr-discord">Dapr Discord server</a> and the <a href="https://microcks.io/discord-invite/">Microcks Discord server</a>!</p>
]]></content:encoded>
					
		
		
			</item>
		<item>
		<title>Linux Foundation Appoints Jonathan Bryce as Executive Director, Cloud &#038; Infrastructure and Chris Aniszczyk as CTO, Cloud &#038; Infrastructure to Oversee Major Open Source Initiatives</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/announcements/2025/06/24/linux-foundation-appoints-jonathan-bryce-as-executive-director-cloud-infrastructure-and-chris-aniszczyk-as-cto-cloud-infrastructure-to-oversee-major-open-source-initiatives/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[kthornhill]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Jun 2025 15:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Announcements]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=135383</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[Bryce will serve as executive director of CNCF and OpenInfra Foundation in dual role SAN FRANCISCO, June 24, 2025 ‚Äî The Linux Foundation, the nonprofit organization enabling mass innovation through open source, today announced the appointment...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p><strong><em>Bryce will serve as executive director of CNCF and OpenInfra Foundation in dual role</em></strong></p>



<p><strong>SAN FRANCISCO, June 24, 2025 </strong>‚Äî <a href="http://www.linuxfoundation.org">The Linux Foundation</a>, the nonprofit organization enabling mass innovation through open source, today announced the appointment of <a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/jbryce/">Jonathan Bryce</a> as Executive Director, Cloud &amp; Infrastructure and Chris Aniszczyk as CTO, Cloud &amp; Infrastructure. Both will oversee the Linux Foundation‚Äôs largest cloud and infrastructure open source initiatives, including the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), where Bryce will also serve as Executive Director.¬†</p>



<p>‚ÄúJonathan brings decades of experience building thriving open source communities at the intersection of infrastructure and innovation for the OpenInfra Foundation and Chris has done the same for the CNCF, ‚Äù said Jim Zemlin, Executive Director of the Linux Foundation. ‚ÄúTheir combined leadership will instill new momentum across cloud native, infrastructure, and AI projects at the Linux Foundation, and ensure our communities and members continue to benefit from the most critical open source technologies on the planet.‚Äù</p>



<p>Adoption of open source software is <a href="https://www.library.hbs.edu/working-knowledge/open-source-software-the-nine-trillion-resource-companies-take-for-granted">central to competitive innovation</a>, supported worldwide by a community of passionate and dedicated developers. As the leader of Cloud &amp; Infrastructure for the Linux Foundation, Bryce will establish a foundational strategy that unites and elevates open source technologies that underpin everything from cloud native development to generative AI and digital strategies.&nbsp;</p>



<p>&#8220;The Linux Foundation is home to some of the most impactful technologies in the world, and ensuring the health, sustainability, and growth of these projects is my top priority,&#8221; said Bryce. ‚ÄúAs the leader of Cloud &amp; Infrastructure, I‚Äôll work to nurture existing projects and identify new opportunities to solve emerging challenges in areas like AI, edge computing, and sustainable tech. I‚Äôm grateful for the opportunity and energized by the communities driving open source innovation.‚Äù</p>



<p>As CTO of Cloud &amp; Infrastructure, Aniszczyk expands his role to serve banner Linux Foundation projects like OpenInfra, driving developer-facing initiatives, sharing successful lessons from the growth of CNCF with other organizations and broadening the impact of cloud and infrastructure technology, globally.</p>



<p>‚ÄúThe success of open source innovation begins and ends with developers and in this next phase of growth for the Linux Foundation, I will work to ensure that this group remains vibrant and our true north star,‚Äù said Aniszczyk. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm thrilled to grow my sphere of influence, working with new communities, technologies and organizations that share my dedication to open source.‚Äù</p>



<p>As Executive Director of the CNCF, Bryce will guide the more than 200 projects under the foundation. He will work with the foundation‚Äôs 700+ members to facilitate collaboration and engagement within the cloud native community. Bryce will also remain the Executive Director of the OpenInfra Foundation, home of the OpenStack project, emphasizing the shared impact both foundations have on driving the adoption of open source infrastructure to support AI, edge, and cloud native workloads.&nbsp;</p>



<p>‚ÄúI see enormous collaboration potential between CNCF and OpenInfra‚Äîboth are essential components of modern, production-grade infrastructure,‚Äù continued Bryce. ‚ÄúMy goal is to strengthen the connections across these communities, leveraging our shared experience and insights facilitating closer partnerships and strategic alignment across the broader open-source ecosystem.‚ÄùTo learn more about Bryce‚Äôs plans as Executive Director for the CNCF, please read his blog post <a href="https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/06/24/joining-cncf-as-executive-director-lets-build-whats-next/">here</a>. To learn more about the CNCF, visit <a href="http://www.cncf.io">www.cncf.io</a>. To learn more about the Linux Foundation, visit <a href="http://www.linuxfoundation.org">www.linuxfoundation.org</a>.</p>



<p></p>
]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Joining CNCF as Executive Director: Let&#8217;s Build What&#8217;s Next</title>
		<link>https://www.cncf.io/blog/2025/06/24/joining-cncf-as-executive-director-lets-build-whats-next/</link>
		
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Jonathan Bryce]]></dc:creator>
		<pubDate>Tue, 24 Jun 2025 15:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
				<category><![CDATA[Blog]]></category>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.cncf.io/?p=135381</guid>

					<description><![CDATA[The CNCF community represents the best of open source: innovative, passionate, diverse, and collaborative. It‚Äôs a community reshaping how the world runs software in production, and I‚Äôm excited to serve as the new Executive Director. I...]]></description>
										<content:encoded><![CDATA[
<p>The CNCF community represents the best of open source: innovative, passionate, diverse, and collaborative. It‚Äôs a community reshaping how the world runs software in production, and I‚Äôm excited to serve as the new Executive Director.<br><br>I want to take a moment to thank Priyanka Sharma for her leadership over the past five years. Under her guidance, CNCF has expanded its global reach, positively impacting countless organizations and people around the world. I‚Äôm grateful for the foundation she‚Äôs built and excited to carry this momentum forward.</p>



<p>As someone who‚Äôs spent more than 15 years building open source communities, I know firsthand the importance of maintaining trust, fostering open collaboration, and empowering maintainers and contributors. For me, leading CNCF is an opportunity to amplify these values at an even larger scale in support of the community that is&nbsp; fundamentally transforming technology and business worldwide.&nbsp;</p>



<p>It is also an opportunity to create unprecedented strategic alignment between the foundational infrastructure layer of OpenInfra, and the cloud native application layer of CNCF, two of the most important ecosystems in open source. For years, the industry has been working to bridge these worlds, and my dual role is designed to do exactly that‚Äî foster deeper collaboration, reduce friction, and create a more seamless experience for the developers and users who rely on both.</p>



<p>My long-term vision is for CNCF to remain the indispensable home for cloud native innovation. This means doubling down on the community and governance frameworks that have made our projects the choice for modern enterprises and staying one step ahead of what‚Äôs coming next, including the massive scale and hardware complexity that come with operating AI platforms.</p>



<p>One of the initial priorities I have set for myself is to tune into the voices of maintainers, contributors, end users, and member organizations and understand where support is most needed. Engaging and listening helps me determine the best approaches to key decisions we are facing: how do we continue to scale our support for an ever growing number of projects, how do we determine the right integration points between cloud native and other ecosystems, and how do we improve the scalability and security of these systems in production use? Feedback is the way, and I am all ears.</p>



<p>I look forward to working alongside Chris Aniszczyk and the entire CNCF leadership team to understand your needs, ensure transparency in our processes, and foster alignment around the work that matters most.</p>



<p>Our success won‚Äôt be measured simply by stars or downloads, but by the lasting impact we make as a community. Cloud native isn‚Äôt a passing trend; it‚Äôs the backbone of modern computing. Together, let‚Äôs continue to shape its future. Let‚Äôs build what‚Äôs next.</p>
]]></content:encoded>
